headline.main: White House May Look to Compromise on Contraception Decision

docs.abstract: The Obama administration has faced resistance over a new rule that requires insurance plans at some religious institutions to cover birth control.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration has faced resistance over a new rule that requires insurance plans at some religious institutions to cover birth control.

docs.lead_paragraph: 10:48 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

headline.main: White House May Look to Compromise on Contraception Decision

docs.abstract: The Obama administration last month unveiled new rules requiring insurance plans at some religious institutions to provide free contraception to their employees.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration last month unveiled new rules requiring insurance plans at some religious institutions to provide free contraception to their employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The insurer’s profit was up, but shares fell as its full-year outlook failed to meet Wall Street’s expectations.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Rick Santorum poised to do well in the Minnesota caucuses, the Romney campaign issues statements attacking him on spending.

headline.seo: Heading Midwest, Romney Takes Aim at Santorum
headline.main: As Campaign Heads to Midwest, Romney Turns His Focus to Santorum
headline.print_headline: As Campaign Heads to Midwest, Romney Turns His Focus to Santorum

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney shifts his attacks to Republican presidential contender Rick Santorum, who appears poised to do well in several upcoming primaries in the Midwest; criticizes Santorum for his federal spending and health care policies in effort to eliminate rival that could possibly threaten Romney's march to win the nomination.
docs.snippet: With Rick Santorum poised to do well in the Minnesota caucuses, the Romney campaign issues statements attacking him on spending.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in both parties say they want to give doctors a small increase in Medicare payments, but they cannot agree on how to pay for it.

headline.seo: House and Senate at Impasse on Medicare
headline.main: House and Senate at Impasse on Medicare Payments
headline.print_headline: House and Senate at Impasse on Medicare Payments

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators are deadlocked over how to prevent a deep cut in payments to doctors who treat millions of Medicare beneficiaries, an impasse that could threaten broader legislation on a payroll tax cut; lawmakers in both parties say they want to give doctors a small increase, but cannot agree on how to cover the cost.
docs.snippet: Lawmakers in both parties say they want to give doctors a small increase in Medicare payments, but they cannot agree on how to pay for it.

docs.abstract: There's some potentially good news for the thousands of overseas nationals living in Turkey and confused about their legal and health-care status. Turkish authorities have scheduled a meeting with overseas diplomats in Ankara for Thursday to clarify the new universal health insurance mandate.
docs.snippet: There's some potentially good news for the thousands of overseas nationals living in Turkey and confused about their legal and health-care status. Turkish authorities have scheduled a meeting with overseas diplomats in Ankara for Thursday to clarify...

docs.lead_paragraph: There's some potentially good news for the thousands of overseas nationals living in Turkey and confused about their legal and health-care status. The Sosyal Guvenlik Kurumu, or Social Security Institution, has scheduled a meeting with overseas diplomats in Ankara for Thursday, Feb. 9, to clarify the new universal health insurance mandate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether you can obtain a job, credit or insurance can be based on your digital doppelgänger — and you may never know why you’ve been turned down.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law Prof Lori Andrews warns that there are many ways that companies can use data garnered from Internet users' online activity to negatively impact one's life.
docs.snippet: Whether you can obtain a job, credit or insurance can be based on your digital doppelgänger — and you may never know why you’ve been turned down.

docs.lead_paragraph: Government manufacturing policies must go beyond the belief that it’s better to produce “real things” than services. People value health care and haircuts as much as washing machines and hair dryers.

headline.seo: Do Manufacturers Need Special Treatment? - Economic View

docs.abstract: Christina D Romer Economic View column contends government manufacturing policies must go beyond the belief that it is better to produce 'real things' than services; holds the economic rationales for a policy aimed specifically at shoring up manufacturing largely fall into three not completely convincing categories: market failures, jobs and income distribution.
docs.snippet: Government manufacturing policies must go beyond the belief that it’s better to produce “real things” than services. People value health care and haircuts as much as washing machines and hair dryers.
